text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

The traditional classroom and
the traditional case method

get relaxed to experiment with a
variety of different pedagogies

to capture a hot
topic in real time.

Direct-to-consumer is
merely a channel, not
a business strategy.

Even though it's only
been 10, 15 years

since DTC businesses, or
digitally-native brands,

have really taken off, the space
has evolved pretty quickly.

I don't feel like anyone has
taken a step back from 20,000

feet and looked at the entire
industry from beginning to end,

and that's what we're
attempting to do here.

We have 29 visitors
who are generous enough

to come to class and
toss their problems
in the hands of our students.
What was the time frame--

What's the founder journey
like from the first iteration
to the last?

The ongoing operating
businesses have

been gracious enough to provide
us with their earliest pitch
decks.

And so the students
will walk away

with a sense of what worked
and what didn't work.

--this case is all
about better is better--

Should I be on Amazon
when I launch my business?

Where and how you might want
a celebrity to work with you,

and what economic
value a celebrity
brings to the equation.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

That's just a sampling of
what you can do in four days.

Help students avoid
some of the mistakes,

or investors not make
some of the mistakes
they might have otherwise made.

And then ultimately,
in real time,

grapple with the same dilemmas
entrepreneurs and founders
are grappling with.

And frankly, be better at
whatever it is they plan to do.
[APPLAUSE]
